messages.msgSnippet: Cheers Jim, much appreciated. The plate does look to have good age, the inlay pics aren t great ( they always seem a bit soft ) but they look like they are
messages.messageBody:
Cheers Jim, much appreciated. The plate does look to have good age, the
inlay pics aren't great ( they always seem a bit soft ) but they look
like they are original, though I am not completely sure about that.

appreciated as always

Rich

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Tsuba school
messages.msgSnippet: Rich, The plate looks older than the decoration -- it might be pre-Edo period.  The tsuba would probably be attributed to Shoami (or Ko-Shoami if the inlay
messages.messageBody:
Rich,
The plate looks older than the decoration -- it might be pre-Edo period. The tsuba would probably be attributed to Shoami (or Ko-Shoami if the inlay turns out to be original). It's handsome even if the jidai is mixed.

Jim


all, I have had this one for a little while and am still unsure of an
attribution. It looks like it has good age and the Vajra are well made.
I was thinking late 17th or early 18th century ? maybe a bit older.

cheers

Rich Turner

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: tsuba motifs
messages.msgSnippet: I agree with kiri leaf mon at about 1:00 and 7:00.  Probably gourds at 3:00 and 9:00.  The birds lack long necks, so they re probably not geese.  The things at
messages.messageBody:
I agree with kiri leaf mon at about 1:00 and 7:00. Probably gourds at 3:00
and 9:00. The birds lack long necks, so they're probably not geese. The
things at ~5:00 and 11:00 look like folding fans as David said. Rather than
a koto bridge, I think that the curving elements are positive relief stems
for the negative relief gingko leaves formed next to the kiri/gourd. It
looks like the middle of the stem is missing from the left side, but the end
of the stem is there at the top.

I don't know what the combined meaning is. Both gourds and kiri were
associated with Hideyoshi. Gingko is a samurai loyalty symbol and is
associated with shrines and temples. They're also planted around the
Imperial palace grounds in Tokyo, although I don't know if they're old
enough to have been there when it was Tokugawa property. If the birds are
swallows that would go with the moat. I can't think of anything specific
about the fans. Anyway, just thinking out loud, I don't know what it adds
up to. Maybe some particular shrine or scenic spot? The gourds and fans
for an outdoor party held there?

Jim



Hi all, yes, I am as is Ron is on this, I see the geese and I also think
Kiri mon, though there appears to be Gourds or Eggplant at the ends of
these mon ?. Could that be a bridge, the shape with the supports ?.

Nice whatever it is, looks Bushû maybe.

cheers

Rich Turner
